properties.name: Auschwitz concentration camp
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14birkenauAuschwitz concentration camp was used to keep jews hostage during World War 2. It was one of the deadliest concentration camps during the war. Right away women and babies were killed by the gas chambers and then thrown into the fire to be burned. Millions were killed by starvation, injuries and many were killed by Nazi soldiers. It was the most miserable place to be. Although many survived or escaped it will forever be burned into the minds of the victims.

properties.name: Grand Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14Grand CanyonAbout two summers ago my family went to the Grand Canyon. We had a reall good time. The Grand Canyon is basically a big hole in the ground. I wasn\'t very excited at first but when we got there it was unbelievable. We were there for like two hours. The rocks have a unique look to them and are in a variety of hundreds of colors smeared across them. I had great time looking at the amazingness of it all!!!

properties.name: Lincoln Memorial
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14Washington D.C.The Lincoln Memorial stands at the west end of the National Mall as a monument to the 16th president. The memorial was designed by Henry Bacon and stands at 190 ft long,119 ft wide, and 100 ft high. It is surrounded by 38 Doric columns that are represented by the 36 states in the Union at the time of Lincoln\'s death. Congress approved the construction of the memorial in 1910. Construction began in 1914 and the memorial was opened to the public in 1922. It is visited by millions each year and has survived some damage but still stands tall.

properties.name: St. Augustine
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14FloridaSt. Augustine is located in north Florida. It is the oldest city in America and was founded by the Spanish in 1565. A Catholic Mass celebrated in St. Augustine was the first Christian worship service held in a permanent settlement in the United States. St. Augustine has endured many burnings, invasions and other battles. It still to this day is a major tourist spot in Florida. You can see old fort ruins and see how people lived back in Floridas first years!

properties.name: Statue of Liberty
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14New York CityThe Staue of Liberty was sculpted by Fredric Auguste Bartholdi in 1884. It arrived in New York in July of 1885 on board the Isere which took the statue from France to the United States. The statue was reduced to 350 pieces and was packed into 214 crates. The Statue was reassembled in 4 months and the dedication took place in October 1886. The Statue had to be closed because of September 11 but is now re open to the public. As you can see it is a huge monument and is a major tourist location.

properties.name: Stone Mountain
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14Atlanta,GeorgiaStone mountain is located in Atlanta, Georgia. In 1909 Helen Plane decided to honor General Robert E. Lee by carving a side of the mountain. The first artist contacted was Gutzon Borglum along with 750 men. he began in 1923 and left the project and state in 1925 beacuse of the charges of the project. Augustus Lukeman was the second artis to attempt to carve the mountain. He removed what Borglum began and focused on four central figures, Jefferson Davis, Stonewall Jackson, Robert E. Lee, and a color bearer. Lukeman ran out of time in 1928 because the lease to finish the carving ran out. After the state purchased the land in 1958 Walker Hancock started to carve the mountain again in 1963. in 1970 Spiro Agnew dedicated the carving. It was finally completed in 1972!

properties.name: big ben
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14parisBig Ben was completed in 1858 and stands at 316 feet. It is named after Sir Benjamin Hall the First Commissioner Of Works. Big Ben weighs over 13 tons. It\'s first broadcast was on New Year\'s Eve in 1923. The light above the always lit while Commons is sitting. The clocks mechanism alone weighs 5 tons. The figures on the clocks face are about 2 feet long, the minute hand is 1 ft. square and the copper minute hands are 14 ft long!!

properties.name: eifel tower
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14parisThe Eiffel Tower was made in 1889 for the Paris Exposition. There were over 700 people to choose from to disgn the Eiffel tower but the lucky winner was Alexandre Gustave Eiffel and was assisted by many engineers. However there were many issues that arose during the designing of the Eiffel tower. Nature lovers thought it woul interfere with the birds over Paris no one else really cared. The tower was almost torn down in 1909 because its 20 year lease was up but it was saved. It became useful for television and radio and in 1960 it became a main focus for semioligist Roland Barthes. Over the years it has become a main tourist sight for people all over the world and is useful still for many things in Paris.

properties.name: world trade center site
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14new york cityEveryone knows what happened on September 11 in New York at the World Trade Center so i don\'t need to go into detail. Two years ago i went to New York and got to see the memorial site. There is basically nothing there. But as you can see in the pic there is a cross. I think some of the fireman took what was left and built a memorial for all the lives that were lost. It made me sad but it was pretty awesome.

properties.name: zion canyon national park
properties.description: Posted by Kaley14Â utah?The same time i was at the Grand Canyon we drove to Utah to see the Zion Canyon. It was actually pretty awesome. Instead of standing on the edge of the canyon we got to drive down in it. We ate at a resturaunt. It is like a little town inside. The canyon was absolutely beautiful. It was really green and amazing.
